Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 14th USENIX File and Storage Technologies conference (FAST 2016)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2016 USENIX Symposium on File and Storage Technology (FAST) will be held in Santa Clara, CA. February 22-25. This is the leading conference in storage systems and includes interested participants from across academia and industry. This award is to support students to showcase and discuss their research. Particular interest will be given to broadening participation and supporting students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conference. Special emphasis will be made to sponsor students having no other means of support from their academic departments.

In addition to meeting leading practitioners of storage systems, attending regular program sessions, this year students will also students receiving assistance will be asked to participate in various ways, including: serving as scribes for the conference sessions to write summaries for a later issue of ;login: magazine. A special event is planned for students to meet informally with senior members of the community.

Intellectual Merits. This conference is the premier forum for advanced professionals from academic and industrial backgrounds to meet and discuss the latest research in systems software.

Broader Impacts. Participation in USENIX 2016 provides students with the opportunity to interact with senior researchers in the field, exposes students to cutting edge advances, and is a valuable and important part of the graduate school experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded 27 US-based graduate students to attend the 14th USENIX Symposium on File and Storage Technology (FAST), which took place on February 22-25, 2016 in Santa Clara, CA. The support requested in this proposal made possible the participation of students who would otherwise be unable to attend. USENIX FAST is a leading forum for innovative research in storage systems, gathering many active researchers and practitioners from both industry and academia. Topics include reliability, performance, mobility, power management, measurement, and other topics germane to cutting edge developments in file and storage systems. Participation in leading conferences is an extremely important part of the graduate school experience, providing the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers and to be exposed to advanced work. Total attendance at FAST ’16 was 553, with 111 students from both US and foreign institutions.

In addition to attending the conference sessions, students participated in various ways, including: serving as scribes for the conference sessions to write summaries for a later issue of ;login: magazine, attending the welcome get together/evening reception to interact with senior members of the research community specifically interested in meeting students in a casual and informal atmosphere, board game night, the Women in Advanced Computing networking social, and presenting posters and works in progress.

Intellectual Merits. FAST gathers researchers from across the storage community to foster cross-disciplinary approaches and to address shared research challenges. This collaborative emphasis makes it well-suited for student participation, exposing them to the type of advanced ideas and conversations that should inform their own research and intellectual growth. The opportunity make connections, be published and present their research is invaluable, and plays a significant role in their professional development.

Broader Impacts. Participation in FAST ‘16 and similar conferences is a valuable and important part of the graduate school experience, providing students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers in the field, and exposing them to leading work. FAST offers many opportunities for students to meet, interact, and exchange ideas, including a welcome reception, the poster session and reception, and small birds-of-a-feather sessions in the evenings, as well as the venerable “hallway track”. This interaction is invaluable to job placement; many companies run booths and mini recruiting drives that help both students and industry compete better. This directly helps the U.S. economy. Many of our student grantees have gone on to become important members of the research community, organizing conferences, starting companies, leading cutting edge R&D projects within companies, as well as running their own research groups.

USENIX believes in open access to research, and you can view the FAST ’16 student publications on the FAST web site found here:

https://www.usenix.org/conference/fast16/technical-sessions

The student posters that were presented at FAST ’16 can be viewed in the poster session list here:

https://www.usenix.org/conference/fast16/poster-sessions
The Works in Progress, WiPs, that were presented are listed here: https://www.usenix.org/conference/fast16/work-progress-reports-wips  

 

USENIX thanks the National Science Foundation for this support.
